instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Motherboard <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A check for missing components
threads.message:
Hello guys,

those who have the same logic board, can you please check if you have on your boards actual components like <CHIP>U8160</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q8060</TRANSISTOR> (among others)?
I have received this motherboard for further troubleshooting after previous repair attempt. Now it seems that many components are missing as a result of previous troubleshooting. The labeled components are shown in the attached picture. 
On the other hand, on many used working boards that are sold on ebay, I can see that same components are missing, so this is confusing to me.

threads.title: Motherboard <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A check for missing components
threads.message: Why open another thread? Schematics will tell you unpopulated components. <CHIP>U8160</CHIP> is clearly marked as NO STUFF and <CHIP>U8160</CHIP> has BOM option <SIGNAL>S0PGOOD_ISL</SIGNAL> which is only populated on engineering boards as per BOM options table.

threads.title: Motherboard <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A check for missing components
threads.message: Sorry about that, I started new thread because it was about interpreting labels on the schematics. You have explained it and I understand now. Thank you!
